content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would analyze the payoff matrix to make an informed decision. Here is the simplified matrix:

|    | R | B  |
|---|:--:|:---:|
|R  | 45, 45 | 0, 42  |
|B  | 42, 0   | 12, 12  |

From this matrix, it is clear that the most profitable outcome is when both players choose R. However, choosing R means potentially earning 0 in some rounds (if the other player chooses B). On the other hand, if I always pick B, I will consistently earn 12$ per round, which adds up to a total of $900 over 75 rounds.

Given that this game has 75 rounds, it seems more advantageous to consistently pick B, since the potential higher rewards in some R-R rounds do not compensate for the 33 rounds where I would earn 0 if my opponent chose R (as they have an incentive to deviate from B at least once).

So, my choice would be {B} as a human player.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 12$. Your opponent's payoff is 12$. Please play the next round.
